developercomments: Sometimes the lines between the categories you specified can be a bit blurry, esp. when you go into depths of what rights the agreement itself assigns to an entity and what the license does (e.g. the Mozilla Foundation can issue a new version of the MPL and therefore change the specific license terms while the Committer's Agreement doesn't by itself give Mozilla any special privileges when it comes to licensing changes).

licensenonprofit: I would be equally willing to sign with either
assignmentnonprofit: I am unsure if non-profit/for-profit status would affect my decision
dcononprofit: I am unsure if non-profit/for-profit status would affect my decision
developercomments:
I've wanted to, early in my volunteer status for Mozilla, assign copyright to them. So that future choices to switch licenses in code I wrote/contributed to were possible without my explicit permission. At the time Mozilla had no mechanism for that.

I would be more willing to do a form of copyright assignment as long as I don't lose my own personal ability to use/assign/etc the material as well. (e.g. I can't be sued by the company I assign it to, nor their related partners for the code I wrote, barring other circumstances)

licensenonprofit: I would be more likely to sign with a non-profit entity
assignmentnonprofit: I would be more likely to sign with a non-profit entity
developercomments:
For small fixes — generally to projects I wasn't intending to work on, but happened to spot something small and submitted a fix — I'm very happy to assign any rights over for the project to do whatever it wants with it; I'm not planning on hanging around long-term or being involved any further than that one fix.

For projects I intend to work with in bigger ways and become a contributor to, I want to know what the situation is with copyright and licences. If I'm investing a significant portion of my time, I want to know that the effort is worthwhile, and there isn't a chance of it going missing.

othersigneddetails: Sun's cla created co-ownership of the copyright in the contribution, an interesting middle-path.
developercomments: There is a good bit of misunderstanding out there about CLAs and related docs by both contributors and those that lead/manage projects. I find them an understandable reality, even if annoying, and think it would be great if every project came to see them as a best practice and 2-3 standard agreements became common. That is, we need 'the GPL' of CLAs to emerge so that it can become as frictionless as the GPL did. Apache's CLA is close to this, but people are still confused about it. The OSI, FSF, Linux Fdn, and major distros could lead the way here, but it's unclear they could all agree on messaging around this.

projects: Docker, Hy, Linux, Debian, etc (lots of small ones)
licensenonprofit: I would be equally willing to sign with either
assignmentnonprofit: I am unsure if non-profit/for-profit status would affect my decision
dcononprofit: I would be equally willing to contribute to either
developercomments:
While I'm sure that DCOs and CLAs serve a useful legal purpose, I've found that they have a severe impact on the level of contribution, since they add an arbitrary "paperwork" barrier to entry that is otherwise not present and doesn't improve the functionality of the contribution in any other way.

An open source project's most valuable resource is the time that is freely donated to it by contributors, and any distraction of that time on paperwork and overhead essentially redirects that contributor's donated time to the dump.

I just follow the FSF's advice when working on my own: https://www.fsf.org/blogs/rms/assigning-copyright

licensenonprofit: I would be more likely to sign with a non-profit entity
assignmentnonprofit: I would not sign with either
dcononprofit: I would be more likely to contribute to a non-profit entity
obstaclereason[other]: I only contribute to permissively licensed projects
developercomments:
Personally, I try to only contribute under permissive licenses, like MIT/BSD or Apache.  I believe permissive-license fans are often under-represented in the FLOSS community public discussion not because we have any "less" belief and desire to use our license (versus copyleft fans), but mostly because copyleft fans tend to be much louder and more demanding in their promotion of copyleft.

Note that this is a separate discussion from commercial companies; i.e. I believe there are many independent developers who prefer permissive licenses personally, not just because of their employer.

licensenonprofit: I would only sign with a non-profit entity
assignmentnonprofit: I would only sign with a non-profit entity
dcononprofit: I would be equally willing to contribute to either
developercomments: The recent proliferation of copyright license agreements risks undermining the viability of traditional free software licenses by providing precedent and legal implication that they are, by themselves, insufficient to protect the interests of the projects, their contributors and users. I do not believe this to be the case, as quite a lot of design effort (including from interested legal policy authors and defenders) has gone into the design of modern open source and free software licenses. Further, contributor license agreements have a "chilling effect" on contributions to free software projects, since they are all too often also used in various forms to nefarious ends by companies wishing to leverage community labor in production of "open core" software and similar exploitative business models.

developercomments: I personally find the legal arguments surrounding CLAs to be mostly theoretical and pointless. I don't know of a single legal case that has been decided based on whether someone or some group signed or did not sign a particular CLA. Therefore, I view the whole concept of CLAs as decidedly a make-work effort for and by lawyers with nothing better to do with their time.

developercomments: I think CLA's are a barrier to contribution. I prefer software licenses like Apache 2 that explicitly cover contributions as part of the original license.  Using commit records to track contributions seems more practical as it's nearly transparent, even though the projects I contribute to don't require an explicit "Signed off by" note.

licensenonprofit: I would be more likely to sign with a non-profit entity
assignmentnonprofit: I would be more likely to sign with a non-profit entity

developercomments:
Personally, I'd be somewhat suspicious of a for-profit company asking me to sign a contribution agreement. I'm not really willing to see my work resold for private benefit.

With a non-profit (at least under US law) it's likely that use of my contribution would be constrained by the organization's declared purpose, so I'd be more willing to sign.

dcononprofit: I would be equally willing to contribute to either
developercomments: I feel uneasy about contributor assignments in particular, and to a lesser degree about licence assignments. That unease tends to be reduced in the face of non-profit organisations with a track record of standing up for the rights of individuals over those of organisations and commercial companies. I think I would be very unwilling to assign copyright in a work to a for-profit company (other than an employer) whose incentives were not clearly aligned with those of the project's wider user base.

projects: If I told you it'd identify who I am because that unique combination of projects points only to me, and I'd prefer to be anonymous.
licensenonprofit: Other
licensenonprofit[other]: It depends on who owns and runs the non-profit. A non-profit run as a puppet for a for-profit is the same as the for profit for example. The real issue is what the CLA says and what powers it grants them. Ideally they should not use a CLA at all. Whatever concerns they have should be incorporated into the project's license itself and a CLA not used at all. Secondarily, if a CLA is used it should legally bind the project and entity doing the CLA to keep the software free software at all times (refer to FSF's copyright assignment.) As easy way to do that is not having a CLA at all and simply having a DCO-style thing with everyone keeping their copyright and not granting extra permissions to anyone else that would let them take the software proprietary. If these legal assurances were not presnt I would not agree to a CLA no matter if it's a for-profit or non-profit. This question focuses on the wrong issue.
assignmentnonprofit: Other
assignmentnonprofit[other]: See my other answer to CLA - The answer is the same. I have assigned copyright previously - to the FSF because they've been around for 30 years and have shown themselves to good a good copyright steward. Plus, their CAA obligates the FSF to keep the software free so they can't abuse the trust given. So this question, just like the one on the last page, focuses on the wrong issue. It does affect my decision based on what powers are granted, not necessarily by who gets those powers.
dcononprofit: Other
dcononprofit[other]: I am fine contributing to a kernel.org-style DCO because I retain the copyright and no one gets the power to make it proprietary.
obstaclereason[other]: I declined because their policy specifically allowed my contributions to be able to made proprietary. See my previous answers on CLA & CAA. The policy should legally bind the project to keep the software free at all times.
developercomments: Some of your questions don't focus on the right issues, IMO.

developercomments: Change of license and/or policy to a more strict one, always drives away existing contributors and has unknown effect on future contributions. For example, I have never declined to sign things, but then again I haven't developed any submitable code for projects I wouldn't sign things for. E.g. I disagree with FSF copyright assignment and the treatment that GPL2->3 are "continuiations in spirit of the license" and for example changes to GPL3 drove out Apple contributions to gcc of objc improvements and C. objectives ( see N1451 Blocks proposal), a net loss for gcc I think. Instead they invest in llvm/clang toolchain, which maybe is a more significant impact over they previous gcc efforts. A net win for total # of opensourced code?!

I'm not sure I currently understand the need to sign a document to provide a patch to a project.
